awd_titl_txt: An investigation of the impact of culture and experience on reasoning about complex ecological phenomena among students from diverse backgrounds
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. The project will conduct research designed to deepen our fundamental knowledge about culture, experience, and ecosystems cognition and to develop innovative practices and approaches to support learning about changing ecological systems and environmental decision making. Work on cultural differences in the production of complex systems knowledge is severely lacking. This gap in knowledge may contribute to the continued reproduction of inequities in science education. More broadly findings from this project will have clear implications for theories of cognitive development, especially those pertaining to how knowledge is shaped by culture and experience. Focusing on ecosystems may represent an opportunity to not only increase engagement and achievement in science among non-dominant communities and Native youth specifically, but also advance effective learning for all communities. The primary deliverables for the project are conference presentations and research publications. However, the project will also develop additional resources freely available to researchers, educators, and the general public. These will include summer curricular materials and teaching tools, professional development workshops, practitioner briefs about research findings that can be used in professional development workshops and shared share more broadly, and evaluation reports.

A deeper understanding of cultural influences on conceptions of the natural world can serve to advance the educational needs of children, including children from diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds. Project research will include two interrelated series of studies and is designed to expand knowledge about human cognition of (complex) ecosystems and the affordances of informal STEM learning environments in developing and supporting the critical 21st century skill of ecological systems level reasoning. The first consists of a series of experiments focused on ecological cognition and the role of humans in nature. The second consists of design-based research interventions in informal settings, summer workshops for youth and the communities, focused on ecological systems level thinking and socio-environmental decision making. The project will recruit and engage both child and adult participants from two broad cultural communities, Native Americans and European Americans living in urban and suburban communities, in part because it affords a sharp test of human-nature relations. Sampling from two different urban communities will avoid simple Native-non-Native comparative binaries and to conduct Native-to-Native comparative analysis. Based on results from this, the project will result in: 1) foundational knowledge about human learning and reasoning and ecosystems and environmental decision making, 2) culturally responsive models of learning and practice about complex ecosystems for indoors and outdoors informal learning environments, and 3) insights about research-practice-community partnerships. One important objective of the research is to broaden participation and close opportunity gaps for under-represented groups in STEM fields broadly and more specifically for Indigenous people. As in past research conducted by the project, members of Indigenous communities, who provide strong role models for other aspiring scholars, will be involved as postdoctoral fellows, research assistants and graduate fellows.

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to produce 1) foundational knowledge about human learning and reasoning and ecosystems and environmental decision making, 

2) culturally responsive models of learning and practice about complex ecosystems for indoors and outdoors informal learning environments, and 

3) insights about research- practice-community partnerships around critical 21st century issues. 

Across our project we have explored the ways in which culture and experience impact human reasoning and environmental decision-making. Several key findings including: 1) Human perspectives about their relationships and place within the natural world shape reasoning and decision-making. These perspectives seem to shift across the life course but not in a clear linear trajectory. In our work younger children and older adults overlapped in perspectives – at least within Native American communities. However, we also learned that Native children and youth often had two forms of reasoning about the natural world and environmental decision-making and the impacts on the future.  The first way of thinking is what we might call the self-determining position – where children would name that if what they and their communities wanted were to happen then here would be a more sustainable future. The second way of thinking that children and youth articulated was about whether or not they thought those in power, which was not perceived as their own tribal communities, would engage in sustainable decision-making and action. Often children and youth expressed they did not think that would happen. An addition key finding from work across cultural communities is that priming people to engage in reasoning from the perspective that humans are a part of the natural world had significant impacts on their decision-making in experimental tasks. These findings suggest that there are important systemic opportunities to re-infrastructure humans as a part of the natural world, given previous researches finding that the majority of cultural artifacts and representations position humans as a part from the natural world.

 

We have designed and implemented a range of educational programming across the project specifically focused on Native learners in a urban Native community. Our key finding from this dimension of the work focuses on the power of being grounded in Indigenous Knowledge Systems with generative mediation between western knowledge systems can create very robust learning where Native learners cultural identities and knowledge, intellectual/disciplinary identities and knowledge, wellbeing and leadership and agency stances exponential grow. In addition we have found that intergenerational learning and learning environments that occur on and with land and water is foundational to transformative learning.

 

Finally our project utilized community based participatory design research. We utilized this approach in part because it is a method that recognize, honors and supports the regeneration of educational self-determination and capacity in Indigenous communities on their own terms. This process seems to follow some important stages. First, co-design must take seriously the impacts and the historical educational legacies that have impacted Native communities. However, the process must reach to not allow this to be definitional. Indigenous communities had and have educational models that are not only driven by harm. Centering decision-making in these strengths and paradigms is critically important.  Second, there seems to be a phase in which community designers engage in deep creative work and many ideas and programs begin to be implemented. A phase that seems to arise after the creative burst is the ways in which systemic structures that hold different values and ideas about what is valuable education comes into tension with community generated education. Finally, issues of sustainability and capacity arise.  Importantly this reflects an important systemic perspective across time is central to co-design and an important area of program design that is under-developed in co-design research.

 

Several key publications from this project includes:

Bang, M. (2020). Learning on the move toward just, sustainable, and culturally thriving futures. Cognition and Instruction, 38(3), 434-444.

McDaid Barry, N., Bang, M., Bruce, F., & Barajas-López, F. (2023). “Then the Nettle People Won’t Be Lonely”: Recognizing the Personhood of Plants in an Indigenous STEAM Summer Program. Cognition and Instruction, 41(4), 381-404.

Bruce, F., Bang, M., Lees, A., McDaid, N., Peters, F., & Bushnell, J. (2023). Indigenous water pedagogies: Cultivating relations through the reading of water. Occasional Paper Series, 2023(49), 2.

Lees, A., & Bang, M. (2023). Indigenous pedagogies: Land, water, and kinship. Occasional Paper Series, 2023(49), 1.

Novack, M. A., Standley, M., Bang, M., Washinawatok, K., Medin, D., & Waxman, S. (2022). Hands on: Nonverbal communication in Native and non-Native American parent–child dyads during informal learning. Developmental psychology, 58(1), 32.

Bang, M., Gurneau, J., Faber, L., Marin, A., Marin, M., Medin, D., ... & Woodring, J. (2023). Perspective Taking and Psychological Distance in Children’s Picture Books: Differences between Native and Non-Native Authored Books. In Indigenous STEM Education: Perspectives from the Pacific Islands, the Americas and Asia, Volume 1 (pp. 123-140). Cham: Springer International Publishing.
